channel.title: Norming
channel.description: A succinct podcast about norms. One episode per month, 10 minutes per episode. No more, no less.
channel.itunes:author: Michael McAndrew

item.title: The Wayback Machine
item.description: The library of Alexandria was one of the most famous libraries of the ancient world. The library was supposedly burned down, and with it, all the years of intellectual progress contained within it. This was the inspiration of a very Silicon Valley project, the Wayback machine.
item.content:encoded: The library of Alexandria was one of the most famous libraries of the ancient world. The library was supposedly burned down, and with it, all the years of intellectual progress contained within it. This was the inspiration of a very Silicon Valley project, the Wayback machine.
item.itunes:summary: The library of Alexandria was one of the most famous libraries of the ancient world. The library was supposedly burned down, and with it, all the years of intellectual progress contained within it. This was the inspiration of a very Silicon Valley project, the Wayback machine.

item.title: The Five-Day Work Week
item.description: The 40 hour, 5 day work week became the norm for industrialised countries almost 90 years ago, and it hasn’t changed much since. So why are we still working on average 8 hours a day, 5 days a week, and does it still work all these years later?
item.content:encoded: The 40 hour, 5 day work week became the norm for industrialised countries almost 90 years ago, and it hasn’t changed much since. So why are we still working on average 8 hours a day, 5 days a week, and does it still work all these years later?
item.itunes:summary: The 40 hour, 5 day work week became the norm for industrialised countries almost 90 years ago, and it hasn’t changed much since. So why are we still working on average 8 hours a day, 5 days a week, and does it still work all these years later?

item.title: Guinness
item.description: Some European countries like France or Italy are known for incredible food cultures. Ireland on the other hand, is better known for their drinking than eating. Our Whiskey's and Coffee's are fairly well known worldwide, but we’re probably best known for Guinness. It is, after all, our national drink. So what makes a national drink, and why is Guinness ours?
item.content:encoded: Some European countries like France or Italy are known for incredible food cultures. Ireland on the other hand, is better known for their drinking than eating. Our Whiskey's and Coffee's are fairly well known worldwide, but we’re probably best known for Guinness. It is, after all, our national drink. So what makes a national drink, and why is Guinness ours?
item.itunes:summary: Some European countries like France or Italy are known for incredible food cultures. Ireland on the other hand, is better known for their drinking than eating. Our Whiskey's and Coffee's are fairly well known worldwide, but we’re probably best known for Guinness. It is, after all, our national drink. So what makes a national drink, and why is Guinness ours?

item.title: Domain Names
item.description: There's a fantastic list of the most expensive domain names on Wikipedia. The most expensive so far is voice.com that was bought for $30 million. So why are domain names going for such crazy sums of money these days?
item.content:encoded: There's a fantastic list of the most expensive domain names on Wikipedia. The most expensive so far is voice.com that was bought for $30 million. So why are domain names going for such crazy sums of money these days?
item.itunes:summary: There's a fantastic list of the most expensive domain names on Wikipedia. The most expensive so far is voice.com that was bought for $30 million. So why are domain names going for such crazy sums of money these days?

item.title: Leap Years
item.description: Happy leap year! It's pretty easy to figure out when we have a leap year, right? Nothing about time is what it seems. Let's find out why.
item.content:encoded: Happy leap year! It's pretty easy to figure out when we have a leap year, right? Nothing about time is what it seems. Let's find out why.
item.itunes:summary: Happy leap year! It's pretty easy to figure out when we have a leap year, right? Nothing about time is what it seems. Let's find out why.

item.title: Locks
item.description: Most people feel a sense of security when they lock something that they own. But this sense of security is misplaced. Most locks that we use in our homes can be picked in a few minutes flat. So why do we still use them?
item.content:encoded: Most people feel a sense of security when they lock something that they own. But this sense of security is misplaced. Most locks that we use in our homes can be picked in a few minutes flat. So why do we still use them?
item.itunes:summary: Most people feel a sense of security when they lock something that they own. But this sense of security is misplaced. Most locks that we use in our homes can be picked in a few minutes flat. So why do we still use them?

item.title: CAPTCHA
item.description: CAPTCHA is a test to distinguish humans from computers on the internet. But with computers becoming better at things that were previously only possible by humans, does it still work today?
item.content:encoded: CAPTCHA is a test to distinguish humans from computers on the internet. But with computers becoming better at things that were previously only possible by humans, does it still work today?
item.itunes:summary: CAPTCHA is a test to distinguish humans from computers on the internet. But with computers becoming better at things that were previously only possible by humans, does it still work today?

item.title: Daylight Saving Time
item.description: If you live in one of 70 odd countries with Daylight Saving Time, changing your clocks twice a year is a normal part of life. But in the rest of the world in this day and age, this practice seems bizarre. Should we just do away with it altogether?
item.content:encoded: If you live in one of 70 odd countries with Daylight Saving Time, changing your clocks twice a year is a normal part of life. But in the rest of the world in this day and age, this practice seems bizarre. Should we just do away with it altogether?
item.itunes:summary: If you live in one of 70 odd countries with Daylight Saving Time, changing your clocks twice a year is a normal part of life. But in the rest of the world in this day and age, this practice seems bizarre. Should we just do away with it altogether?

item.title: Bonus: World Standards Day
item.description: Happy World Standards Day 2023! To celebrate, I rate every norm featured on Norming to date, on a five-star scale.
item.content:encoded: Happy World Standards Day 2023! To celebrate, I rate every norm featured on Norming to date, on a five-star scale.
item.itunes:summary: Happy World Standards Day 2023! To celebrate, I rate every norm featured on Norming to date, on a five-star scale.

item.title: Postcodes
item.description: Ireland didn't get a postcode system until 2015, which makes it one of the newest in the world. So what does a postcode for the 21st Century look like? And how does it compare to its contemporaries?
item.content:encoded: Ireland didn't get a postcode system until 2015, which makes it one of the newest in the world. So what does a postcode for the 21st Century look like? And how does it compare to its contemporaries?
item.itunes:summary: Ireland didn't get a postcode system until 2015, which makes it one of the newest in the world. So what does a postcode for the 21st Century look like? And how does it compare to its contemporaries?

item.title: Plugs
item.description: The topic of the best plug has been hotly debated by patriotic plug enthusiasts around the world, claiming that their plug is better than all others. So the question is, who is right and who is wrong?
item.content:encoded: The topic of the best plug has been hotly debated by patriotic plug enthusiasts around the world, claiming that their plug is better than all others. So the question is, who is right and who is wrong?
item.itunes:summary: The topic of the best plug has been hotly debated by patriotic plug enthusiasts around the world, claiming that their plug is better than all others. So the question is, who is right and who is wrong?

item.title: A4–The Perfect Paper Size
item.description: If you've ever had the displeasure of dividing up an A4 sheet of paper with a ruler, you'll know that it measures 210x297mm. Conveniently short enough to measure with a standard ruler. But the question remains, why 297mm and not the more convenient 300mm?
item.content:encoded: If you've ever had the displeasure of dividing up an A4 sheet of paper with a ruler, you'll know that it measures 210x297mm. Conveniently short enough to measure with a standard ruler. But the question remains, why 297mm and not the more convenient 300mm?
item.itunes:summary: If you've ever had the displeasure of dividing up an A4 sheet of paper with a ruler, you'll know that it measures 210x297mm. Conveniently short enough to measure with a standard ruler. But the question remains, why 297mm and not the more convenient 300mm?

item.title: Electric Cars
item.description: If I wanted to buy a new car in 1910, I'd have three drivetrain options to choose from, steam, internal combustion or electricity. Over 100 years later, electricity is making a comeback again. Does history have any hints as to how successful we might be this time?
item.content:encoded: If I wanted to buy a new car in 1910, I'd have three drivetrain options to choose from, steam, internal combustion or electricity. Over 100 years later, electricity is making a comeback again. Does history have any hints as to how successful we might be this time?
item.itunes:summary: If I wanted to buy a new car in 1910, I'd have three drivetrain options to choose from, steam, internal combustion or electricity. Over 100 years later, electricity is making a comeback again. Does history have any hints as to how successful we might be this time?

item.title: Recommended for You
item.description: Chances are if you've ever sneaked a look at someone else's YouTube, Netflix or Spotify home page, you'll see a very different place to your own. Recommendation systems are so personalised these days that a recommended feed almost feels like an invasion of privacy.
item.content:encoded: Chances are if you've ever sneaked a look at someone else's YouTube, Netflix or Spotify home page, you'll see a very different place to your own. Recommendation systems are so personalised these days that a recommended feed almost feels like an invasion of privacy.
item.itunes:summary: Chances are if you've ever sneaked a look at someone else's YouTube, Netflix or Spotify home page, you'll see a very different place to your own. Recommendation systems are so personalised these days that a recommended feed almost feels like an invasion of privacy.

item.title: Accept All Cookies?
item.description: The web has become cluttered with pop-ups asking for our consent to cookies and tracking policies. So how did we get here, what is a cookie and why do we have to accept them just to be able to browse the web?
item.content:encoded: The web has become cluttered with pop-ups asking for our consent to cookies and tracking policies. So how did we get here, what is a cookie and why do we have to accept them just to be able to browse the web?
item.itunes:summary: The web has become cluttered with pop-ups asking for our consent to cookies and tracking policies. So how did we get here, what is a cookie and why do we have to accept them just to be able to browse the web?

item.title: A Sign of the Times
item.description: An unfortunate paradox of successful typefaces is that, the more wide their use is, the less noticeable they become. And there is possibly no typeface that this is more true for than Times New Roman. So how did it reach such ubiquity that it became a icon of the word processing age? And how did it ultimately eventually fall out of fashion?
item.content:encoded: An unfortunate paradox of successful typefaces is that, the more wide their use is, the less noticeable they become. And there is possibly no typeface that this is more true for than Times New Roman. So how did it reach such ubiquity that it became a icon of the word processing age? And how did it ultimately eventually fall out of fashion?
item.itunes:summary: An unfortunate paradox of successful typefaces is that, the more wide their use is, the less noticeable they become. And there is possibly no typeface that this is more true for than Times New Roman. So how did it reach such ubiquity that it became a icon of the word processing age? And how did it ultimately eventually fall out of fashion?

item.title: Credit or Debit?
item.description: Recently while visiting the United States I noticed that nearly every time I used my debit card to make a payment I was asked if I would like to pay with "credit or debit". Curiosity took the better of me and I occassionally said "Credit" to see what would happen. The payment still successfully went through each time. If it would work either way, why ask the question?
item.content:encoded: Recently while visiting the United States I noticed that nearly every time I used my debit card to make a payment I was asked if I would like to pay with "credit or debit". Curiosity took the better of me and I occassionally said "Credit" to see what would happen. The payment still successfully went through each time. If it would work either way, why ask the question?
item.itunes:summary: Recently while visiting the United States I noticed that nearly every time I used my debit card to make a payment I was asked if I would like to pay with "credit or debit". Curiosity took the better of me and I occassionally said "Credit" to see what would happen. The payment still successfully went through each time. If it would work either way, why ask the question?

item.title: Film Frame Rates
item.description: In December 2009, the first Avatar film was released in cinemas. The film pushed the boundaries of what was possible in cinema at the time, and made the film industry consider strongly the use of 3D. Twelve years later, James Cameron is back at it again, this time experimenting with high frame rates.
item.content:encoded: In December 2009, the first Avatar film was released in cinemas. The film pushed the boundaries of what was possible in cinema at the time, and made the film industry consider strongly the use of 3D. Twelve years later, James Cameron is back at it again, this time experimenting with high frame rates.
item.itunes:summary: In December 2009, the first Avatar film was released in cinemas. The film pushed the boundaries of what was possible in cinema at the time, and made the film industry consider strongly the use of 3D. Twelve years later, James Cameron is back at it again, this time experimenting with high frame rates.

item.title: The 12 Note Tuning System
item.description: There are 12 notes in the Western system of tuning and I've always been curious as to why we settled on 12 notes in particular. A 10 note system seemed particularly logical to me. It turns out that the answer is somewhat of a mystery.
item.content:encoded: There are 12 notes in the Western system of tuning and I've always been curious as to why we settled on 12 notes in particular. A 10 note system seemed particularly logical to me. It turns out that the answer is somewhat of a mystery.
item.itunes:summary: There are 12 notes in the Western system of tuning and I've always been curious as to why we settled on 12 notes in particular. A 10 note system seemed particularly logical to me. It turns out that the answer is somewhat of a mystery.

item.title: PDF
item.description: Adobe has been in the news lately after their contraversial deal to buy Figma. No better time to remind ourselves of one of their better contributions to the world, PDF.
item.content:encoded: Adobe has been in the news lately after their contraversial deal to buy Figma. No better time to remind ourselves of one of their better contributions to the world, PDF.
